    <dl>
           <dt>na 1</dt>
           <dd><em>na</em> the dental nasal (found at the beginning of words and before or after dental consonants as well as between vowels </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; subject to conversion into ? <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 8-4, 1-39). = 1</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; nak&#x0101;ra </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;k&#x0101;ra</em> m. the sound or letter <em>n</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in prosody) a tribrach </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-vipul&#x0101;</em> f. a kind of metre</dd>

           <dt>na 2</dt>
           <dd><em>n&#x00e1;</em> ind. not, no, nor, neither <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> (<em>n&#x0101;</em>, x, 34, 8) &amp;c. &amp;c. (as well in simple negation as in wishing, requesting and commanding, except in prohibition before an Impv. or an augmentless aor. [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#a">a.</a> <em>m&#x0101;</em>] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in successive sentences or clauses either simply repeated, e.g. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a>iv, 34 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or strengthened by another particle, esp. at the second place or further on in the sentence, e.g. by <em>u</em> [cf. <em>n&#x00f4;</em>], <em>ut&#x00e1;</em>, <em>api</em>, <em>c&#x00e2;pi</em>, <em>v&#x0101;</em>, <em>v&#x00e2;pi</em> or <em>atha v&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 170, 1 ; 151, 9 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nal">Nal.</a> iii, 24, &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it may even be replaced by <em>ca</em>, <em>v&#x0101;</em>, <em>api ca</em>, <em>api v&#x0101;</em>, &amp;c. alone, as <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a>&#x012b;, 98 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nal">Nal.</a>i, 14, &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; often joined with other particles, beside those mentioned above esp. with a following <em>tu</em>, <em>tv eva</em>, <em>tv eva tu</em>, <em>c&#x00ea;d</em>, q.v., <em>khalu</em>, q.v., <em>ha</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#g">g.</a> <em>c&#x00e2;di</em> and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 8-1, 31] &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; before round or collective numbers and after any numeral in the instr. or abl. it expresses deficiency, e.g. <em>ekay&#x0101; na vi&#x1e43;&#x015b;ati</em>, not 20 by 1, i.e. 19 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>pa&#x00f1;cabhir na catv&#x0101;ri &#x015b;at&#x0101;ni</em>, 395 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with another <em>na</em> or an <em>a</em> priv. it generally forms a strong affirmation [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> V&#x0101;m. v, 1, 9], e.g. <em>n&#x00ea;ya&#x1e43; na vak&#x1e63;yati</em>, she will most certainly declare <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> iii, 9 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>n&#x00e2;da&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;yo'sti</em>, he must certainly be punished <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> viii, 335 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it may also, like <em>a</em>, form compounds <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;m">V&#x0101;m.</a> v, 2, 13 [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#below]">below].</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; that not, lest, for fear lest (with Pot.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;">Da&#x015b;.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; like, as, as it were (only in Veda and later artificial language, e.g. <em>gauro na t&#x1e5b;&#x1e63;ita&#x1e25; piba</em>, drink like [lit. 'not', i.e. 'although not being'] a thirsty deer </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in this sense it does not coalesce metrically with a following vowel). [Cf. Gk. ? ; Lat. [523, 1] [nË˜e-] ; Angl. Sax. <em>ne</em>, 'not' ; Eng. <em>no</em>, &amp;c.] -2</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; nak&#x0101;ra </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;k&#x0101;ra</em> m. the negation <em>na</em>, the word No <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naish">Naish.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; naki&#x1e43;cana </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;ki&#x1e43;cana</em> mfn. having nothing, very poor <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;c">Pa&#x00f1;c.</a> (cf. <em>a-k&#x25cb;</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; naki&#x1e43;cid </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;ki&#x1e43;cid</em> n. nothing <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-api-sa&#x1e43;kalpa</em> m. no desire for anything <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; nakim </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kim</em> ind. = <em>na-k&#x012b;m</em> g. <em>c&#x00e2;di</em></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; nakis </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kis</em> (<em>n&#x00e1;-</em>), ind. no one, nobody <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = next <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> (g. <em>c&#x00e2;di</em> </dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; nak&#x012b;m </dt>

           <dt>&#x22d9; naciketa </dt>

           <dt>&#x22d9; nacira </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>ena</em>, <em>&#x0101;t</em>, <em>&#x0101;ya</em>), ind. id., shortly, soon </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x25cb;ra-nir&#x012b;k&#x1e63;in</em> mfn. not seeing very far <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-do&#x1e63;ala</em> mfn. not of too bad quality or nature <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-drava</em> mfn. not too liquid <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-drutam</em> ind. not too quick <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vish&#x1e47;">Vish&#x1e47;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-dhanin</em> mfn. not too rich, Agp </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-nirbhagna</em> mfn. not too much bent <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-nirv&#x1e5b;tti</em> f. not too much ease <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-n&#x012b;ca</em> mfn. not too low <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhag">Bhag.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-parikara</em> mfn. having little attendance <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;">Da&#x015b;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-parisphu&#x1e6d;a</em> mfn. not fully displayed <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-pary&#x0101;pta</em> mfn. not too abundant <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-pu&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a</em> mfn. not too much provided with (instr.), D&#x0101;&#x015b; </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; prob. fr. &#x221a;<em>nak&#x1e63;</em>, cf. <em>nak&#x1e63; dy&#x0101;m</em>, i, 33, 14 &amp;c.) a star or any heavenly body </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also applied to the sun </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. sg. sometimes collectively 'the stars', e.g. vii. 86, 1 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an asterism or constellation through which the moon passes, a lunar mansion <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (27, later 28, viz. &#x015a;ravish&#x1e6d;h&#x0101; or Dhanish&#x1e6d;h&#x0101;, &#x015a;ata-bhishaj, P&#x016b;rva-bh&#x0101;drap&#x0101;da, Uttara-bh&#x1e6d;bh&#x0101;drap&#x0101;da, Revat&#x012b;, A&#x015b;vin&#x012b;, Bhara&#x1e47;&#x012b;, K&#x1e5b;ittik&#x0101;, Rohi&#x1e47;&#x012b; or Br&#x0101;hm&#x012b;, M&#x1e5b;iga-&#x015b;iras or &#x0100;grah&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;&#x012b;, &#x0100;rdr&#x0101;, Punarvas&#x016b; or Y&#x0101;makau, Pushya or Sidhya, &#x0100;&#x015b;lesh&#x0101;, Magh&#x0101;, P&#x016b;rva-phalgun&#x012b;, Uttara-ph&#x1e6d;phalgun&#x012b;, Hasta, Citr&#x0101;, Sv&#x0101;t&#x012b;, Vi&#x015b;&#x0101;kh&#x0101; or R&#x0101;dh&#x0101;, Anur&#x0101;dh&#x0101;, Jyesh&#x1e6d;ha, M&#x016b;la, P&#x016b;rv&#x00e2;sh&#x0101;&#x1e0d;h&#x0101;, Uttar&#x00e2;sh&#x1e6d;&#x0101;&#x1e0d;h&#x0101;, Abhijit, &#x015a;rava&#x1e47;a </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; according to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> Revat&#x012b;, Uttara-phalgun&#x012b;, Uttara-bh&#x0101;drap&#x0101;da and Uttar&#x00e2;sh&#x0101;&#x1e0d;ha are called <em>dhruv&#x0101;&#x1e47;i</em>, fixed </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in the Vedas the Nakshatras are considered as abodes of the gods or of pious persons after death <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;y">S&#x0101;y.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 50, 2 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; later as wives of the moon and daughters of Daksha <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; according to Jainas the sun, moon, Grahas, Nakshatras and T&#x0101;r&#x0101;s form the Jyotishkas) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a pearl <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; probably invented to explain <em>nagna</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; nagna </dt>
           <dd><em>nagn&#x00e1;</em> mf(<em>&#x0101;&#x0341;</em>)n. naked, new, bare, desolate, desert <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. a naked mendicant (esp. a Bauddha, but also a mere hypocrite) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Var">Var.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; pf. <em>nan&#x0101;da</em>, <em>nedur</em>, <em>nedire</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. [anË˜AdIt] Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>nadi&#x1e63;yati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;dit&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a>) to sound, thunder, roar, cry, howl &amp;c.            <dd>&#x2022; <em>n&#x0101;dayati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em>, to make resonant, fill wish noises or cries <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>an&#x012b;nadat</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Pass. <em>n&#x0101;dyate</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a>: Desid. <em>ninadi&#x1e63;ati</em> Gr.: Intens. 3. pl. <em>n&#x0101;&#x0341;nadati</em>, p. <em>n&#x0101;&#x0341;nadat</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 3. sg. <em>n&#x0101;nadyate</em>, p. <em>&#x25cb;dyam&#x0101;na</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> to vibrate or sound violently, to roar, howl, cry, neigh &amp;c</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; nada </dt>
           <dd><em>nad&#x00e1;</em> m. a roarer, bellower, thunderer, crier, neigher &amp;c. (as a cloud, horse, bull, met. a man, i, 179, 4) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> viii, 58, 2 (beginning with <em>nadam</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a river (if thought of as male, ifc. ind. <em>-nadam</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>nad&#x012b;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dt>nanu </dt>
           <dd><em>na-n&#x00fa;</em> ind. (2. <em>n&#x00e1;</em> + <em>nu</em>) not, not at all, never <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> ; (interr.) not? is it not? = nonne <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (hence often = ) certainly, surely, indeed, no doubt (esp. in questions amounting to an affirmation, e.g. <em>nanv aha&#x1e43; te priya&#x1e25;</em>, am I not your friend, i.e. certainly I am your friend <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;">Da&#x015b;.</a> [so also <em>na ca</em>, there can be no doubt <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 2-3, 11 ; 29 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a>], or to a request, e.g. <em>nanu gacch&#x0101;mi</em> <em>bho&#x1e25;</em>, surely I may go <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 8-1, 43 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a>, and even as a responsive particle, e.g. <em>ak&#x0101;r&#x1e63;&#x012b;&#x1e25; ka&#x1e6d;amnanu karomi bho&#x1e25;</em>, indeed I have made it <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with another interr. or an Impv. = pray, please, e.g. <em>nanu ko bhav&#x0101;n</em>, pray who are you? <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x1e5b;icch">M&#x1e5b;icch.</a> x, 48/49 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>nan&#x016b;7cyat&#x0101;m</em>, please tell <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> 52/53 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in argument often as an inceptive particle implying doubt or objection, 'now it may be said, well, but then' &amp;c., esp. in <em>nanv astu</em>, or <em>nanu m&#x0101; bh&#x016b;t-tath&#x00e2;pi</em>, well, be it so or not so-nevertheless) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a vocat. particle implying kindness or reproach or perplexity &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>nantavya </dt>
           <dd><em>nantavya</em> mfn. (&#x221a;<em>nam</em>) to be bent or bowed </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be saluted or honoured <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a></dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; changing a dental to a cerebral <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RPr&#x0101;t">RPr&#x0101;t.</a></dd>

           <dd><em>n&#x00e1;ntva</em> mfn. to be bent <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ii, 24, 2</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>nandi&#x1e63;yate</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a>, <em>&#x25cb;di&#x1e63;yati</em> and <em>&#x25cb;dit&#x0101;</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>anand&#x012b;t</em> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; aor. P. <em>an&#x0101;n</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x1e6d;h">K&#x0101;&#x1e6d;h.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ana&#x1e43;s&#x012b;t</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;">Da&#x015b;.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>na&#x1e43;syati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>nami&#x1e63;yati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>nant&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Siddh">Siddh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>-n&#x00e1;mam</em>, <em>-n&#x00e1;me</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>nantum</em>, <em>namitum</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ind. p. <em>natv&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-natya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-namya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a>) to bend or bow (either trans. or oftener intr ) to bow to, subject or submit, one's self (with gen., dat. or acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with <em>hiruk</em>) to turn away, keep aside <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> iv, 1, 3 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to turn towards, i.e. to aim at (gen.) with (instr.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 165, 6 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to yield or give way, keep quiet or be silent <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#B&#x0101;lar">B&#x0101;lar.</a> vi, 12 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in gram.) to change a dental letter into a cerebral <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RPr&#x0101;t">RPr&#x0101;t.</a>: Pass. <em>namyate</em>, to be bent or bowed </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; yield or submit to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TUp">TUp.</a> iii, 10, 4: Caus. <em>nam&#x00e1;yati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (<em>n&#x0101;mayati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Up">Up.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>n&#x0101;myati</em> [!] <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x1e5b;icch">M&#x1e5b;icch.</a> i, 30 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>an&#x012b;namat</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Pass. <em>n&#x0101;myate</em>, <em>&#x25cb;ti</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c.) to cause to bow or sink, incline <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with <em>c&#x0101;pam</em>) to bend a bow <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to turn away or ward off <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to aim at (gen.), ix, 97, 15 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in gram.) to change a dental letter into a cerebral <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RPr&#x0101;t">RPr&#x0101;t.</a>: Desid. <em>nina&#x1e43;sati</em>, G&#x1e5b;.: Intens. <em>n&#x00e1;nnam&#x012b;ti</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>nannamyate</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r">K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r.</a> (3. sg. <em>n&#x00e1;mnate</em> impf. <em>anamnata</em>, p. <em>n&#x00e1;mam&#x0101;na</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a>) to bow or submit one's self to (dat.). <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> [Cf.            <dt>nayyagrodha </dt>
           <dd><em>n&#x00e1;yyagrodha</em> mf(<em>&#x012b;</em>)n. (fr. <em>nyagrodha</em>) relating to the sacred fig-tree <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> (v&#x1e37;. <em>naiyagr&#x25cb;</em>)</dd>

           <dt>nara </dt>
           <dd><em>n&#x00e1;ra</em> m. (cf. <em>n&#x1e5b;</em>) a man, a male, a person (pl. men, people) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; husband <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> ix, 76 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; hero <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> iv, 31 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#B&#x0101;lar">B&#x0101;lar.</a> viii, 56 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a man or piece at chess or draughts &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the pin or gnomon of a sun-dial <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x016b;ryas">S&#x016b;ryas.</a> (cf. <em>-yantra</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; person, personal termination <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 3-1, 85 (cf. <em>puru&#x1e63;a</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the primeval Man or eternal Spirit pervading the universe (always associated with N&#x0101;r&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a, 'son of the primeval man' <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p529-1"></a>[Page 529, Column 1]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; both are considered either as gods or sages and accordingly called <em>devau</em>, <em>&#x1e5b;&#x1e63;&#x012b;</em>, <em>t&#x0101;pasau</em> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in ep. poetry they are the son, of Dharma by M&#x016b;rti or A-hi&#x1e43;s&#x0101; and emanations of Vish&#x1e47;u, Arjuna being identified with Nara, and K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a with N&#x0101;r&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> (cf. <em>-s&#x016b;nu</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (pl.) a class of myth. beings allied to the Gandharvas and Ki&#x1e43;-naras <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> . <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a son of Manu T&#x0101;masa <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a son of Vi&#x015b;v&#x0101;mitra <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a son of Gaya and father of Vir&#x0101;j <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a son of Su-dh&#x1e5b;iti and father of Kevala <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a son of Bhavan-manyu (Manyu) and father of Sa&#x1e43;k&#x1e5b;iti <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>

           <dd><em>n&#x00e1;raka</em> (cf. Nir </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; there are many different hells, generally 21 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> iv, 88-90 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> &amp;c.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m.            <dd>&#x2022; of a son of Vipra-citti <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; m. or n. N. of a place of pilgrimage <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> (v&#x1e37;. <em>anaraka</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>ik&#x0101;</em>), f. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 7-3, 44 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;rtt">V&#x0101;rtt.</a> 4 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; nalin&#x012b; 1</dt>
           <dd><em>nalin&#x012b;</em> f. (fr. <em>nalina</em> above or fr. <em>nala</em> 'lotus' as <em>ab-jin&#x012b;</em> fr. <em>ab-ja</em>, <em>padmin&#x012b;</em> fr. <em>padma</em> &amp;c.) a lotus, Nelumbium Speciosum (the plant or its stalk), an assemblage of lotus flowers or a lotus pond <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the Ganges of heaven or rather an arm of it <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a myst. N. of one of the nostrils <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; he took possession of Indra's throne but was afterwards deposed and changed into a serpent <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> vii, 41 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> &amp;c.            <dd>&#x2022; descended from Nahusha (?), x, 63, 1</dd>

           <dt>nahi </dt>
           <dd><em>na-h&#x00ed;</em> (<em>n&#x00e1;-h&#x00ed;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MaitrS">MaitrS.</a> and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a>), ind. (g. <em>c&#x00e2;di</em>) for not, surely not, by no means, not at all (often strengthened by other particles, as <em>a&#x1e45;g&#x00e1;</em>, <em>n&#x00fa;</em>, <em>sma</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (<em>nahikam</em> g. <em>c&#x00e2;di</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; nahim&#x0101;tra </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;m&#x0101;tra</em> m. or n. a partic. high number (v&#x1e37;. <em>mantra</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Buddh">Buddh.</a> (cf. <em>na-m&#x0101;sra</em> under 2. <em>n&#x00e1;</em>)</dd>

           <dt>n&#x0101; </dt>

           <dt>n&#x0101;ka </dt>
           <dd><em>n&#x0101;&#x0341;ka</em> m. (&#x221a;<em>nam</em>[?] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; according to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nir">Nir.</a> fr. 2. <em>n&#x00e1;</em> + 2 <em>-&#x00e1;ka</em>, 'where there is no pain' [?] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 6-3, 75 and below mfn. ) vault of heaven (with or scil. <em>div&#x00e1;s</em>), firmament, sky (generally conceived as threefold, cf. <em>tri-diva</em>, <em>tri-n&#x0101;ka</em>, and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> xix, 27, 4 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> xvii, 67 there is a fivefold scale, viz. <em>p&#x1e5b;thivii</em>, <em>antari-k&#x1e63;a</em>, <em>div</em>, <em>divo-n&#x0101;ka</em>, and <em>svar-jyotis</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the sun <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naigh">Naigh.</a> i. 4 </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; of a dynasty <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> </dd>

           <dd><em>n&#x0101;g&#x00e1;</em> m. (prob. neither fr. <em>na-ga</em> nor fr. <em>nagna</em>) a snake, (esp.) Coluber Naga <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (f. <em>&#x012b;&#x0341;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Supar&#x1e47;">Supar&#x1e47;.</a>) a N&#x0101;ga or serpent-demon (the race of Kadru or Su-ras&#x0101; inhabiting the waters or the city Bhoga-vat&#x012b; under the earth </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; they are supposed to have a human face with serpent-like lower extremities [see esp. Nag. v, 17 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 233 &amp;c.] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; their kings are &#x015a;esha, V&#x0101;suki, and Takshaka <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> 323 ; 7 or 8 of the N&#x0101;gas are particularly mentioned <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with Buddhists they are also represented as ordinary men <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MWB">MWB.</a> 220) <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p533-1"></a>[Page 533, Column 1]</font> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; the best or most excellent of any kind (ifc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> (cf. <em>&#x1e5b;&#x1e63;abha</em>, <em>vy&#x0101;ghra</em> &amp;c.) </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; of the effects of that period on anything happening during it <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>

           <dt>n&#x0101;bhij&#x0101;ta </dt>
           <dd><em>n&#x00e2;bhij&#x0101;ta</em> <em>n&#x00e1;bhim&#x0101;na</em> &amp;c. under 2. <em>n&#x00e1;</em></dd>

           <dt>n&#x0101;ma 1</dt>
           <dd><em>n&#x0101;&#x0341;ma</em> ind. (acc. of <em>n&#x0101;&#x0341;man</em>) by name i.e. named, called <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (also with <em>n&#x0101;matas</em> and <em>n&#x0101;mn&#x0101;</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; indeed, certainly, really, of course <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; quasi, only in appearance <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#J&#x0101;takam">J&#x0101;takam.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; however, nevertheless <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; after an interr. = then, pray, e.g. <em>ki&#x1e43; n&#x25cb;</em>, <em>katha&#x1e43; n&#x25cb;</em>, <em>kad&#x0101;</em> nevertheless, what then? pray, what? &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; after an Impv. = may it be so, no matter, e.g. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> v, 8 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>api n&#x25cb;</em> at the beginning of a sentence = perhaps, I dare say, e.g. <em>apy e&#x1e63;a n&#x0101;ma phalam icchati</em>, this man wants perhaps a reward <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x1e5b;icch">M&#x1e5b;icch.</a> viii, 25 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with Pot. often = would that, e.g. <em>api n&#x0101;ma&#x012b;7va&#x1e43; sy&#x0101;t</em>, would that it were so <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vikr">Vikr.</a> v, 19/20 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; opp. to <em>m&#x0101; n&#x25cb;</em> with Pot. would that not, I should think not, e.g. <em>m&#x0101; n&#x0101;ma ak&#x0101;sya&#x1e43; kury&#x0101;t</em>, I hope he will not do something wrong <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x1e5b;icch">M&#x1e5b;icch.</a> iii, 26</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; n&#x0101;ma 2</dt>
           <dd><em>n&#x0101;ma</em> in comp. for <em>n&#x0101;man</em>, q.v. (sometimes ifc. as in <em>satya-</em>, q.v.)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; n&#x0101;makara&#x1e47;a </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; n. the calling of a person (gen.) by the name of (<em>n&#x0101;mn&#x0101;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sarvad">Sarvad.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the ceremony of naming a child after birth <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kau&#x015b;">Kau&#x015b;.</a> &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 370 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x25cb;ra&#x1e47;a&#x1e43;</em> &#x221a;<em>k&#x1e5b;</em>, to perform this child) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; by name, namely (often with 1. <em>n&#x0101;ma</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; ifc. f. either = m. or <em>&#x25cb;mn&#x012b;</em>) a characteristic mark or sign, form, nature, kind, manner <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; name, appellation <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>nama-gotra</em> above) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 8-2, 23 (often ifc. = named, called, e.g. <em>vi&#x1e63;&#x1e47;u-&#x015b;arma-n&#x0101;m&#x0101; pa&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;itah</em>, a sage named Vish&#x1e47;u) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; merely the name (as opp. to reality </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>n&#x0101;ma-dh&#x0101;raka</em>, <em>-m&#x0101;tra</em>, <em>-&#x015b;e&#x1e63;a</em> &amp;c.), a noun (as opp. to a verb) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nir">Nir.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pr&#x0101;t">Pr&#x0101;t.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; substance, essence (in the Mimi&#x1e43;s&#x0101; phil. opp. to <em>gu&#x1e47;a</em>, accidental quality) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a good or great name, renown, fame (only ifc </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>&#x015b;va-</em>, <em>sum&#x00e1;ntu-</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; water <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naigh">Naigh.</a> i, 11 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>n&#x0101;&#x0341;mn&#x0101;</em> ind. by name (also joined with 1. <em>n&#x0101;ma</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with &#x221a;<em>k&#x1e5b;</em> (Kav.) or <em>vi-dh&#x0101;</em> (cf. Kath&#x0101;s.) to call by a name </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>n&#x0101;ma</em> (q.v.) with &#x221a;<em>grabh</em> (<em>grah</em>) to mention or address by name <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with &#x221a;<em>bh&#x1e5b;</em>, to bear or have a name <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with &#x221a;<em>k&#x1e5b;</em> (cf. Br. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> &amp;c.), &#x221a;<em>d&#x0101;</em> or <em>dh&#x0101;</em> (G&#x1e5b;S), to give a name call. [Cf. Zd. <em>n&#x0101;man</em> </dd>

           <dd><em>n&#x0101;r&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;&#x00e1;</em> m. (patr. fr. <em>n&#x00e1;ra</em>, q.v.) the son of the original Man (with whom he is generally associated, e.g. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> i, 10 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he is identified with Brahm&#x0101; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> 11 with Vish&#x1e47;u or K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#T&#x0100;r">T&#x0100;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the Apsaras Urva&#x015b;&#x012b; is said to have sprung from his thigh <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> 4601 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; elsewhere he is regarded as a Ka&#x015b;yapa or A&#x1e45;girasa, also as chief of the S&#x0101;dhyas, and with Jainas as the 8th of the 9 black V&#x0101;sudevas) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the Purusha-hymn (Ry. x, 90, said to have been composed by N&#x0101;r&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;&#x00e1;) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (as synonym of Vish&#x1e47;u) N. of the 2nd month (reckoning from M&#x0101;rga&#x015b;&#x012b;rsha) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Var">Var.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a mystical N. of the letter <em>&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Up">Up.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a son of Aj&#x0101;-mila <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; of a son of Nara-hari, Kshitt&#x00ee;s </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of sev. men, authors and commentators (also with <em>&#x0101;c&#x0101;rya</em>. <em>kavi</em>, <em>g&#x0101;rgya</em>, <em>cakra-c&#x016b;&#x1e0d;&#x0101;ma&#x1e47;i</em>, <em>daiva-vid</em>, <em>dharm&#x00e2;dhik&#x0101;rin</em>, <em>pa&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ina</em>, <em>pa&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ita</em>, <em>dharm&#x00e2;dkik&#x0101;ri&#x1e45;</em> <em>pa&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;it&#x00e2;c&#x0101;rya</em>, <em>parivr&#x0101;j</em>, <em>bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;a</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#below,">below,.</a> and <em>bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;a-n&#x25cb;</em>], <em>bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;&#x00e2;c&#x0101;rya</em>, <em>bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;&#x00e2;ra&#x1e0d;a</em>, <em>bh&#x0101;rat&#x012b;</em>, <em>bhi&#x1e63;aj</em>, <em>muni</em>, <em>yati</em>, <em>yat&#x012b;7vara</em>, <em>r&#x0101;ya</em>, <em>vandya</em>, <em>v&#x0101;d&#x012b;7&#x015b;vara</em>, <em>vidy&#x0101;-vinoda</em>, <em>vai&#x1e63;&#x1e47;ava-muni</em>, <em>&#x015b;arman</em>, <em>sarasvat&#x012b;</em>, <em>sarva-j&#x00f1;a</em>, <em>s&#x0101;rvabhauma</em>) </dd>

           <dd><em>n&#x0101;&#x0341;r&#x012b;</em> f. (of <em>&#x25cb;r&#x00e1;</em>, q.v.) a woman, a wife (in older language also <em>n&#x0101;&#x0341;ri</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; having no object (cf. below) </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; n. opium <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> (cf. <em>a-ph&#x25cb;</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; nis </dt>
           <dd><em>n&#x00ed;s</em> ind. out, forth, away &amp;c. (rarely used as an independent word [e.g. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> vi, 18, 3 ; vii, 115, 3 ; xvi, 2, 1], but mostly as a prefix to verbs and their derivatives [cf. <em>ni&#x1e25;-</em> &#x221a;<em>k&#x1e63;i</em> &amp;c. below], or to nouns not immediately connected with verbs, in which case it has the sense, out of', away from' [cf. <em>nirvana</em>, <em>ni&#x1e63;-kau&#x015b;&#x0101;mbi</em> &amp;c.] or that of a privative or negative adverb= 3. <em>a</em>, without', destitute of', 'free from', un-' [cf. <em>nir-artha</em>, <em>nir-mala</em> &amp;c.], or that of a strengthening particle 'thoroughly', entirely', 'very' [cf. <em>nih-&#x015b;&#x016b;nya</em>, <em>ni&#x1e63;-kevala</em>, <em>nir-mu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;a</em>] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it is liable to be changed to <em>ni&#x1e25;</em>, <em>ni&#x015b;</em>, <em>ni&#x1e63;</em>, and <em>ni&#x1e63;</em> and <em>n&#x012b;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#above">above.</a> and below). <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p543-3"></a>[Page 543, Column 3]</font>
</dd>

           <dt>nitya </dt>
           <dd><em>n&#x00ed;tya</em> mf(<em>&#x0101;</em>)n. (fr. <em>ni</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>ni-ja</em>) innate, native <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iii, 13941 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; one's own (opp. to <em>ara&#x1e47;a</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; ifc. constantly dwelling or engaged in, intent upon, devoted or used to (cf. <em>tapo-n&#x25cb;</em>, <em>dharma-n&#x25cb;</em>, <em>dhy&#x0101;na-n&#x25cb;</em>, <em>&#x015b;astra-n&#x25cb;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ordinary, usual, invariable, fixed, necessary, obligatory (opp. to <em>k&#x0101;mya</em>, <em>naimittika</em> &amp;c.)         <br>          <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;rS">&#x015a;rS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> &amp;c.            <dd>&#x2022; with <em>svarita</em> m. = <em>j&#x0101;tya</em>, the independent Svarita <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TPr&#x0101;t">TPr&#x0101;t.</a> ii, 8) </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-hetu</em> m. a regulating cause <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sarvad">Sarvad.</a> </dd>

           <dd><em>&#x016b;ha&#x1e47;a</em> n. ascertainment <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a></dd>

           <dt>nir&#x1e5b; </dt>
           <dd><em>nir-&#x221a;&#x1e5b;</em> (aor. <em>-&#x0101;rata</em> Subj. <em>-ar&#x0101;ma</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ind. p. <em>-&#x1e5b;tya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a>), to go out or off, fall away from, be deprived of (abl. or gen.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 4, 5 ; vii, 56, 21 &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to separate, disjoin <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> x, 2, 2: Caus. <em>-arpayati</em>, to cause to go to pieces or decay, to dissolve, destroy, ruin <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; nir&#x1e5b;ta </dt>
           <dd><em>nir-&#x1e0d;&#x1e5b;ta</em> (<em>n&#x00ed;r-</em>), mfn. dissolved, decayed, debilitated <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 119, 7 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. N. of Rudra <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;yuP">V&#x0101;yuP.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; nir&#x1e5b;ti </dt>
           <dd><em>nir-&#x1e0d;&#x1e5b;ti</em> (<em>n&#x00ed;r-</em>), f. dissolution, destruction, calamity, evil, adversity <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (personified as the goddess of death and corruption and often associated with M&#x1e5b;ityu, A-r&#x0101;ti &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; variously regarded as the wife of A-dharma, mother of Bhaya, Mah&#x0101;-bhaya and M&#x1e5b;ityu [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a>] or as a daughter of A-dharma and Hi&#x1e43;s&#x0101; and mother of Naraka and Bhaya {cf. M&#x0101;rkP.} </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; binds mortals with her cords <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; is regent of the south {<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a>} and of the asterism M&#x016b;la {cf. Var.}) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the bottom or lower depths of the earth (as the seat of putrefaction) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. death or the genius of death <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a Rudra <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of one of the 8 Vasus <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> (v. l. <em>ni-k&#x1e5b;ti</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-g&#x1e5b;h&#x012b;ta</em> (<em>n&#x00ed;r-&#x1e5b;&#x25cb;</em>), mfn. seized by Nir-&#x1e5b;iti <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>-veditum</em>, with v. l. <em>&#x25cb;dayitum</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;k">&#x015a;&#x0101;k.</a>), to tell, communicate, proclaim, report, relate: Caus. <em>-vedayati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> (pf. <em>-veday&#x0101;m &#x0101;sa</em> ind. p. <em>&#x25cb;dayitv&#x0101;</em>, or <em>&#x25cb;dya</em>), id.            <dd>&#x2022; <em>-yauvana</em> mfn. whose youth has returned, restored to y&#x1e6d;youth <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-laulya</em> mfn. whose desire is averted from, not desirous of (comp.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-&#x015b;atru</em> m. 'having one's foes kept off', N. of a king <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-sa&#x1e43;t&#x0101;pa</em> mfn. one whose heat or pain has ceased <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> </dd>

           <dd><em>n&#x012b;-&#x015b;&#x0101;ra</em> <em>n&#x012b;-&#x1e63;ah</em>, <em>n&#x012b;-h&#x0101;ra</em> &amp;c. 5. <em>n&#x012b;</em>, p. 565, col. 2</dd>

           <dt>nu 1</dt>
           <dd><em>n&#x00fa;</em> (in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> also <em>n&#x016b;&#x0341;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; esp. at the beginning of a verse, where often = <em>n&#x00fa;</em> + <em>u</em>), ind. now, still, just, at once </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; so now, now then <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Up">Up.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; indeed, certainly, surely <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 3-2, 121 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a> (often connected with other particles, esp. with negatives, e.g. <em>nah&#x00ed; n&#x00fa;</em>, 'by no means', <em>n&#x00e1;kir n&#x00fa;</em>, no one or nothing at all', <em>m&#x0101;&#x0341; n&#x00fa;</em>, 'in order that surely not' <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p567-2"></a>[Page 567, Column 2]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; often also <em>gha nu</em>, <em>ha nu</em>, <em>in nu</em>, <em>nu kam</em> &amp;c. [<em>n&#x016b;&#x0341; cit</em>, either 'for ever, evermore </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; at once, forthwith' or, never, never more </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; so also <em>n&#x016b;</em> alone <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> vii, 100, 1] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with relat. = -cunque or -soever </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sometimes it lays stress upon a preceding word, esp. an interr. pronoun or particle, and is then often connected with <em>khalu</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; it is also employed in questions, esp. in sentences of two or more clauses [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 8-2, 98 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x015b;">K&#x0101;&#x015b;.</a>] where <em>nu</em> is either always repeated [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> vi, 9] or omitted in the first place [ib. i, 8] or in the second place and further replaced by <em>svid</em>, <em>yadi v&#x0101;</em> &amp;c., and strengthened by <em>v&#x0101;</em>, <em>atha v&#x0101;</em> &amp;c.) [Cf. 1. <em>n&#x00e1;va</em>, <em>n&#x016b;&#x0341;tana</em>, <em>n&#x016b;n&#x00e1;m</em> ; Zd. <em>n&#x016b;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Gk. [567, 2] ? ; Lat. <em>nun-c</em> ; Germ. <em>nu</em>, <em>nun</em> ; Angl&#x1e62;ax. <em>nu</em>, <em>n&#x016b;</em> ; Eng. <em>now</em>.]</dd>

           <dt>nu 2</dt>
           <dd><em>nu</em> m. a weapon <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>anau&#x1e63;it</em>, <em>an&#x0101;vit</em>, <em>anuviit</em> Gr </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; new i.e. curious, strange <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#B&#x0101;lar">B&#x0101;lar.</a> vii, 69 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a> ii, 168/169</dd>

           <dd><em>&#x25cb;ukta</em> mfn. based on etymology, explained etymologically <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; m. (also <em>-uktika</em> g. <em>ukth&#x00e2;di</em>) a knower of the derivation of words, an etymologist <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nir">Nir.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a></dd>

           <dt>nau 1</dt>
           <dd><em>nau</em> encl. acc. dat. gen. du. of 1st pers. pron. (cf. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 8-1, 20) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (cf. VS. also <em>&#x1e47;au</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> VPr&#x0101;t. iii, 85)</dd>

           <dt>nau 2</dt>
           <dd><em>na&#x00fa;</em> f. a ship, boat, vessel <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in astrol.) N. of a partic. appearance of the moon or of a constellation <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Var">Var.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>v&#x0101;c</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nir">Nir.</a> i, 11 (either because prayer is a vessel leading to heaven or ft. &#x221a;4. <em>nu</em>, 'to praise'). [Cf. 2. <em>n&#x0101;va</em> and 7. <em>nu</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Gk. ?, [571, 2] ?, &amp;c. ; Lat. <em>n&#x0101;vis</em>, <em>nau-ta</em>, <em>nau-fragus</em> &amp;c. ; Icel. <em>n&#x00f3;r</em> ; (?) Germ. <em>&#x1e47;achen</em>.]</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; naukar&#x1e47;a </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kar&#x1e47;a</em> m. the helm of a ship (cf. below) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. N. of one of the M&#x0101;t&#x1e5b;is attending on Skanda <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-dh&#x0101;ra</em> m. a helmsman <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Var">Var.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (fig.) governor, ruler, manager <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;d">K&#x0101;d.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; naukarman </dt>

           <dd><em>&#x25cb;rodha</em> m. (&#x221a;<em>rudh</em> = <em>ruh</em>), growing downwards' the Banyan or Indian fig-tree, Ficus Indica (it belongs to the <em>k&#x1e63;&#x012b;ra-v&#x1e5b;k&#x1e63;as</em>, q.v </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; of a Br&#x0101;hman, a monastery and a village <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Lalit">Lalit.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>i</em> or <em>&#x25cb;dhik&#x0101;</em>), f. id. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-k&#x1e63;&#x012b;ra</em> n. the milky juice of the Indian fig-tree <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-parima&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ala</em> mfn. being a fathom in circumference <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MatsyaP">MatsyaP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x25cb;la-t&#x0101;</em> f. the having a waist like a fig-tree, (with <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Buddh">Buddh.</a> one of the 32 signs of perfection <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dharmas">Dharmas.</a> 83) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. an elegant woman <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-p&#x0101;da</em> m. N. of a man </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x25cb;dhaka</em> mfn. g. <em>&#x1e5b;&#x015b;y&#x00e2;di</em> (cf. also above) </dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; nya&#x00f1;c </dt>

           <dd><em>ny-&#x0101;-&#x221a;dh&#x1e5b;</em> only pf. &#x0100;. <em>-dadhre</em>, to be directed towards or fixed upon (loc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> viii, 17, 13</dd>

           <dt>ny&#x0101;n&#x012b; </dt>
           <dd><em>ny-&#x0101;-&#x221a;n&#x012b;</em> (Pot. <em>-nayet</em>), to bring back, restore <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> vii, 38, 5</dd>

           <dt>ny&#x0101;ma </dt>
           <dd><em>ny&#x0101;ma</em> m.= <em>ni-y&#x0101;ma</em>, <em>ni-yama</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>ny&#x0101;ya </dt>
           <dd><em>ny-&#x0101;y&#x00e1;</em> m. (fr. 4. <em>ni</em>) that into which a thing goes back i.e. an original type, standard, method, rule, (esp.) a general or universal rule, model, axiom, system, plan, manner, right or fit manner or way, fitness, propriety <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c. (<em>ny&#x0101;yena</em> and <em>&#x25cb;y&#x0101;t</em>, ind. either 'in the right manner, regularly, duly', or ifc. 'after the manner of, by way of') </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a lawsuit, legal proceeding, judicial sentence, judgment <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x1e5b;icch">M&#x1e5b;icch.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;c">Pa&#x00f1;c.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a logical or syllogistic argument or inference (consisting of a combination of enthymeme and syllogism, and so having, according to the Naiy&#x0101;yikas 5 members, viz. <em>pratij&#x00f1;&#x0101;</em>, <em>hetu</em>, <em>ud&#x0101;hara&#x1e47;a</em>, <em>upanaya</em>, <em>nigamana</em>, or according to the Ved&#x0101;ntins 3 members) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a system of philosophy delivered by Gotama or Gautama (it is one of the six <em>dar&#x015b;anas</em>, q.v., and is perhaps so called, because it 'goes into' all subjects physical and metaphysical according to the above syllogistic method treated of in one division of the system </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; its branch is called Vai&#x015b;eshika) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; likeness, analogy, a popular maxim or apposite illustration (cf. <em>k&#x0101;k&#x00e2;k&#x1e63;i-</em>, <em>ghu&#x1e47;&#x00e2;k&#x1e63;ara-</em>, <em>da&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;&#x00e2;p&#x016b;pa</em>. &amp;c.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>am</em>), ind. after a finite verb expresses either censure or repetition <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 8-1, 27</dd>

           <dd><em>ny-&#x016b;&#x0341;na</em> mf(<em>&#x0101;</em>)n.            <dd>&#x2022; (<em>am</em>) ind. less <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Var">Var.</a> </dd>
